SPRING GROVE RESOURCE RECOVERY ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES



Corporate Statement

Spring Grove Resource Recovery, Inc. (SGRRI) operates a hazardous waste treatment and storage facility (TSDF) in accordance with a RCRA hazardous waste license issued by the Ohio Environmental Protection Agency. SGRRI strives to conduct its business and operations in strict conformity with all applicable laws, and in a safe and responsible manner. SGRRI has always placed the highest priority on the health and safety of its employees and members of the community in which it operates.



SGRRI may be subject to the provisions of the Accidental Release Prevention (ARP) Requirements because regulated toxic and flammable liquids may be present in quantities which may on occasion exceed the regulatory thresholds for these substances. Accordingly, SGRRI has prepared a Risk Management Plan under the U.S. EPA's predictive filing provisions. SGRRI will not exceed the threshold quantities for toxic gases and flammable gases.



SGRRl's accidental release prevention program involves a unified approach that integrates technologies, procedures and management practices. The SGRRI facility is designed, constructed, inspected, maintained and operated in a manner so as to minimize the risk of exposure to employees and the public to hazardous materials managed at the site, and in conformity with all governmental regulations.



SGRRI has a comprehensive inspection plan which requires daily, weekly, monthly. and annual inspections of its processes, equipment and management practices.



SGRRI has a Contingency Plan which prescribes procedures to be followed in the event of a fire or release at the facility. The Contingency Plan includes procedures for notifying local, state and federal emergency response officials of incidents, and specifies arrangements which are made with emergency responders to ensure an effective response in the event of an emergency.



SGRRI has a training p

lan which ensures that each employee receives the training necessary to enable him/her to safely and effectively carry out their job responsibilities. Included in the facility training plan are training modules which instruct employees on the hazards of the regulated substances stored at the site, the procedures for evacuation from the facility, procedures for responding to releases, and procedures for notification of incidents to both facility personnel and offsite emergency responders. In addition to the initial training that all employees receive, each employee receives refresher training on an annual basis.



Risk Management System



Spring Grove Resource Recovery has developed a management system to implement and maintain compliance with the Accidental Release Prevention (ARP) and related chemical safety and emergency response programs. This management system identifies lines of responsibility for the entire program and each of its key elements, as described below.



1. Accidental Release Prevention Program 

Facility General Manager

Facility Compliance Manager

2. Off-Site Hazard Assessment

    Facility Compliance Manager

3. Level 2 Program

Facility General Manger 

Emergency Response Program 

Facility Compliance Manager



This is a predictive filing only since there is a potential for the chemicals described below to be present at the facility on occasion. These chemicals are not routinely stored at the facility in quantities exceeding the threshold planning quantities. Cooperating local response agencies are informed of the actual facility inventories upon request.



DESCRIPTION OF THE FACILITY AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES



SGRRI receives, temporarily stores, consolidates, and ships materials that are classified as hazardous waste under the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA). A review of the records over the past several years indicate that portions of the waste streams may contain greater than one percent of one or more substances regulated

under ARP, and may therefore, have the potential to be received in sufficient quantity to result in SGRRI storing greater than the applicable threshold quantity. The substances and maximum concentrations that could be received are listed below:



Toxic liquids:



Chloroform (20%)

 Formaldehyde (37%

) Hydrochloric Acid (37%

) Toluene 2,4-diisocyanate



No regulated toxic gases or flammable gases are present above threshold quantities at the site. Wastes that may contain more than 1% of any of these regulated substances would be transported to the facility via either enclosed trucks in 55-gallon drums or smaller containers, or in bulk transport vehicles. These wastes may be temporarily stored on-site and then consolidated with other similar1y classified waste streams or they may be directly transferred to other TSDF's for processing. Flammable and toxic wastes are stored in separate areas.



Flammable wastes are pumped from the drums and consolidated into larger tanks that contain mixtures that have a NFPA rating of 3 or less. Therefore, once a regulated flammable substance is pumped into a storage tank, it is no longer subject to ARP.



Toxic substances that are processed are temporarily stored in containers.



The EPA risk management regulation identifies three levels of requirements. Program 2 applies to SGRRI.

GENERAL ACCIDENT/RELEASE PROGRAM/CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



Spring Grove has procedures in place to prevent and mitigate potential releases of toxic and flammable substances. These procedures are detailed in SGRRI's RCRA Part B hazardous waste license. The procedures include, but are not limited to the following:



An inspection program which requires daily, weekly, monthly and annual inspections of process equipment, alarm systems, and management practices, with a procedure for documenting and correcting any deficiencies identified in inspections.



A standard operating procedure for the transfer of flammable and combustible liquids.

A standard operating procedure for ensuring that incompatible materials are not consolidated together.



A waste analysis plan which ensures that the waste received by SGRRI conforms to the waste as initially represented by each generator, and that each waste stream is managed correctly.



A security plan to prevent unknowing or unwanted access to the facility.



A training plan which ensures that each employee at the facility is adequately trained to perform their job duties knowledgeably and safely.



In addition, consistent with ARP regulations, Spring Grove has instituted a Level 2 prevention program consisting of the following elements:



Safety Information including MSDS for regulated substances



Hazard Review



Operating Procedures regarding transfer, storage and processing of regulated substances



Training of workers on operating procedures



Maintenance procedures to maintain mechanical integrity of equipment



Incident Investigation to document spills of regulated substances



Compliance Audits of the prevention program to be conducted every three years.



Also included are the following elements of OSHA's PSM program:



Management of Change





Inventories of the high hazard chemicals are maintained at a low level and they are processed expeditiously so as to minimize both the quantity and the time on site, thereby minimizing risk.



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



During the past 5 years (June 2004 to June 2009), there has been no accident involving any RMP regulated substance that qualifies for reporting under 40 CFR Part 68. This means that no accident has resulted in reportable on-site injury, off-site injury, off-site evacuation or sheltering in place, or damage to property or the environment from a release of such substance.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



It is the policy of Spring Grove to place the highest priority on employee safety and health and on protection of the community from all plant-induced environmental conditions.

An emergency response plan has been developed which prescribes emergency procedures which the facility will implement in the event of a release or fire at the facility.



SGRRl's emergency response plan is identified as the facility Contingency Plan. The purpose of this plan is to describe both the hazards associated with the management of waste materials at the facility and the steps which will be taken to minimize the risk associated with each hazard. By ensuring that proper preventative measures are taken at all times and by providing for emergency response procedures to be followed in the event of any unexpected occurrence(s), SGRRI intends to operate its facility in a manner that does not pose a significant threat to public health, safety or welfare of the environment. SGRRl's record in this regard has been exceptional and its overall contribution to the protection of human health and the environment far surpasses the risks associated with the type of activities performed at the facility.



The specific elements of SGRRl's Contingency Plan include the following:



A general description of the facility operations and the types of hazardous wastes handled at the facility.



A list of the SGRRI emergency coordinators who are responsible for overseeing 

implementation of the Contingency Plan, and their responsibilities.



Criteria for implementing the Contingency Plan.



Emergency Response Procedures, including identification and assessment of an imminent or actual emergency, response procedures for facility personnel, and notification requirements.



A list of emergency equipment.



Coordination agreements between SGRRI and local and state officials.



An evacuation plan.



Incident notification procedures, including procedures for, and content of, initial verbal notifications. SGRRI's Contingency Plan includes the names, addresses, and phone numbers of all local, state and federal emergency response organizations and agencies that are to be notified in

the event of an emergency.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



SGRRI has organized its management system to effectively address all hazards and potential risks. Personnel's training is necessary to support a continual improvement in facility safety. SGRRl's training plan achieves this goal. These programs are all documented so that needed information about the safe handling of all chemicals present at the facility is available to employees, and can be readily interpreted by emergency response team

staff and the Facility Emergency Coordinators when questions arise from public safety officials regarding potential risks to the community. All of these features of the RMP and the integrated risk management program at this site lead to operations that meet or exceed the state and federal regulatory requirements applicable to the facility's operations.
